questions.question_text: A water utility company has seen a dramatic increase in the number of water pumps burning out. A malicious actor was attacking the company and is responsible for the increase. Which of the following systems has the attacker compromised?

An organization's Chief Executive Officer (CEO) directs a newly hired computer technician to install an OS on the CEO's personal laptop. The technician performs the installation, and a software audit later in the month indicates a violation of the EULA occurred as a result. Which of the following would address this violation going forward?

discussion.content:
Abbreviations are difficult for people who are not native English speakers
AUP: acceptable user policy
EULA: end user license agreement
keywords: newly hired computer technician!
AUP is a document that outlines a set of rules. An AUP clearly states what the user (or a newly hired technician) is and is not allowed to do with these resources. It is a simple set of rules that defines how the computer equipment and network can be used (or in this case , should be configured). It could be a small document that every new employee (or technician) needs to read and to sign of.

An end-user license agreement (EULA) is a legal contract entered into between a software developer or vendor and the user of the software, often where the software has been purchased by the user from an intermediary such as a retailer. A EULA specifies in detail the rights and restrictions which apply to the use of the software.
Therefore, the violation of EULA should be part of AUP.

Will go with AUP on this. As stated in GCGA, AUP is the proper system usage or the
rules of behavior for employees when using information technology (IT)
systems. Which also has something to do with the usage of the companies resources. How does the user use it? Is it aligned to the policy? In this case, the CEO asked the technician to install a company owned/purchased OS to his personal laptop. For me, that is bright as day violation on AUP c/o the CEO.
A. Security configuration baseline

Installation that is performed by technician is not installed properly or not has been authorized on CEOs laptop. If a user violates the policy of installing OS or software on the system then that is where AUP comes in.

Generally I am very often confused with this kind of questions... Why? Well, who said that AUP is not already in place? If it is, how we can prevent this, it is only with some technical controls which would be defined in SBC (security configuration baseline)... AUP will not prevent from happening again, SBC will... Very often I see that answers are more related to the administrative controls than to the technical resolution when the question is not precise and defined very well...

comments.content: I am with you here. Although there are no good answers to this quesion I would think Separation of Duties would be best. The CEO shouldn't be directing technicians but instead make a request from the CIO who would be in a better position to make the decision.

discussion.content: Thank you for the explanation, I've been trying to wrap my head around the answer for a while

IMO It doesn't really matter who installed the software and where.
The CEO is using the application and violated the EULA, so the AUP was breached.
